answerText: "The American Scholar"[10] "The American Scholar" was a speech given by this man. In the speech, he suggests that Nature is one of the primary inspirations for a man's development, in reference to his essay Nature.
heading: Penn Bowl |2013 | 5 | 12 | Literature | American | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: This work calls the "mind of the Past" one of the three primary influences for a proper education and suggests that "actions past by" are "a loss of power." [10] Name this work that contrasts the victim of society, the "mere thinker," with Man Thinking.
